datasets.name: Debt to the Penny

fields.definition: Reporting date for the data

All federal debt held by individuals, corporations, state or local governments, Federal Reserve Banks, foreign governments, and other entities outside the United States Government less Federal Financing Bank securities.

Government Account Series securities held by Government trust funds, revolving funds, and special funds; and Federal Financing Bank securities.  A small amount of marketable securities are held by government accounts.
Total of Intragovernmental Holdings and Public Debt

datasets.summaryText:
This report provides information about the total public debt outstanding and is reported each day.

Debt to the Penny is made up of intragovernmental holdings and debt held by the public, including securities issued by the U.S. Treasury. 

U.S. Treasury securities primarily consist of marketable Treasury bills, notes, and bonds as well as savings bonds and special securities issued to state and local governments.

The Debt to the Penny is updated at 3 PM each business day with data from the previous business day.
datasets.tagLine: Debt to the Penny is the total debt of the U.S. government and is reported daily. It is made up of intragovernmental holdings and debt held by the public.

datasets.name: Average Interest Rates on US Treasury Securities

apis.tableName: Average Interest Rates on U.S. Treasury Securities

fields.definition: Reporting date for the data
fields.tableName: Average Interest Rates on U.S. Treasury Securities

fields.definition: Indicates whether a security type is marketable or nonmarketable. Marketable Debt includes Treasury Bills, Notes, Bonds, Floating Rate Notes, and Inflation-Protected Securities where ownership can be transferred from one person or entity to another. They can also be traded on the secondary market. Nonmarketable securities include Savings Bonds, Government Account Series, State and Local Government Series, Domestic Series and Foreign Series securities where legal ownership cannot be transferred.
fields.tableName: Average Interest Rates on U.S. Treasury Securities

fields.definition: Indicates the type of debt instrument issued to raise money needed to operate the federal government and pay off maturing obligations.
fields.tableName: Average Interest Rates on U.S. Treasury Securities

fields.definition: Average Interest Rates are a calculated percentage based on the aggregate interest payments divided by the total debt.  In this table the Total Marketable, Total Nonmarketable, and Total Interest-bearing Debt rates do not include the Treasury Inflation-Indexed Securities and the Treasury Floating Rate Notes.
fields.tableName: Average Interest Rates on U.S. Treasury Securities

datasets.summaryText:
The Average Interest Rates on U.S. Treasury Securities dataset is released monthly and shows the average interest rate on a variety of marketable and non-marketable Treasury securities as well as the previous yearâ€™s average interest rate for comparison.

This is a useful dataset for investors and bond holders to compare how interest rates on Treasury Securities have changed throughout the years.

This dataset is published monthly and is available from calendar year 2001 to the present.
datasets.tagLine: Average Interest Rates for marketable and non-marketable securities over a two-year period.

datasets.summaryText:
The Daily Treasury Statement (DTS) is a series of tables detailing the daily cash and debt operations of the Treasury. 

Information in this report includes the operating cash balance, deposits and withdrawals of cash, public debt transactions, federal tax deposits, short-term cash investments, issues and redemptions of marketable and non-marketable securities, and more. 

All values are millions of dollars. 

This daily information is available beginning in Fiscal Year 1998.
datasets.tagLine: Complete cash and debt operations of the Treasury for each day.

datasets.name: Statistics on Non-Marketable Treasuries Savings Bonds SLGS

apis.tableName: Statistics on Non-Marketable Treasuries Savings Bonds SLGS

datasets.summaryText:
The SLGS Statistics on Non-Marketable Treasuries is a dataset with daily data on how many non-marketable SLGS securities  have been requested for purchase and the amount, including any requests that have been cancelled. 

It also captures the number of issues, redemptions, and securities outstanding along with the dollar amount.

The data is recorded daily for each government fiscal year.

The data for  State and Local Government Securities contains information on many securities have yet to mature and the timeline to maturity, organized in various buckets (0-3 months to maturity, 3-6 months, etc.)
datasets.tagLine: Recap of SLGS transaction and balance activity updated daily including subscriptions, cancellations, issues, outstanding, and redemptions of non-marketable SLGS securities.

datasets.name: Record Setting Auction Data
datasets.summaryText:
This dataset includes the rates, yields, offering, and auction dates of record high and low Treasury bills, notes, bonds, TIPS, FRNs and CMBs.

The only date information in this dataset is the date of auction of record setting Treasury securities.
datasets.tagLine: Rates, yields, offering, and auction dates of record high and low Treasury bills, notes, bonds, TIPS, FRNs and CMBs.

The total count of savings bonds of a particular series and type

Various savings bonds released at different times in history
Bonds that have been officially offered for sale.
Bonds still in circulation that have not been redeemed.

datasets.summaryText:
For each Series of Treasury bonds, this dataset details how many are issued and redeemed, the difference of these two values is how many are outstanding, which is also reported in the dataset. 

It does not contain any information on the values or yields of the Treasury bonds. 

Data in this report dates to the beginning of fiscal year 1999 and is updated monthly.
datasets.tagLine:
Number of Treasury bonds in each series that are issued, redeemed, or Number of Treasury bonds in each series that are issued, redeemed, or 
outstanding from 1998 to today.

datasets.name: Savings Bonds Value Files
datasets.summaryText:
Savings Bond Value Files contains reports detailing the value, earned interest, and yield of savings bonds purchased.

This is the same information found in the Redemption Tables dataset, but in a unique, plaintext format.

These encoded strings were designed for developers and programmers to determine bond values, interest, and yield of savings bonds without having to first convert PDFs.
datasets.tagLine: Encoded, plaintext strings designed for developers and programmers to determine bond values, interest, and yield of savings bonds purchased.

datasets.summaryText:
Redemption Tables is a series of reports with over 100 tables detailing the value, earned interest, and yield of savings bonds purchased.

Each report lists the value of all bonds at the time of publication.

Investors and bond owners can use this table as an easy-to-use reference to determine the value of the bonds which they hold.
datasets.tagLine: Current and historical values, yield, and interest earned for issued Series EE, Series E, and Series I savings bonds as well as Savings Notes.

datasets.summaryText:
This dataset is a summary of five different programs in which states, the District of Columbia (D.C.), and U.S. Territories can collect delinquent debt and turn it over to the Federal government by offset. An offset is the reduction or withholding of a payment.

These programs are income tax, statereciprocal tax agreements, unemployment insurance, child support, and Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP).

Child support is further broken down into administrative offset and tax refund offset. Data is available as far back as Fiscal Year 2000 and is published on a yearly basis.

States vary in their participation of each of the five programs and thus, somefields have null values which are noted.
datasets.tagLine: State and federal collections of delinquent debtfrom five areas: income tax, state reciprocal, unemployment insurance, child support, and SNAP.

datasets.name: Monthly Statement of the Public Debt

fields.definition: Reporting date for the data

Amount outstanding represents the total par (principal amount) of marketable and non-marketable securities outstanding. The marketable securities include the discount and premium for treasury bills, notes, bonds, FRNs, and TIPS, all of which can be bought and sold in the secondary market at prevailing market prices.

datasets.summaryText:
The Monthly Statement of the Public Debt details the Treasuryâ€™s outstanding debts and the debt limit with data going back to 1869. 

Debt is categorized byits ability to be sold in secondary markets (marketability), type of debt, and if the debt is held by the public or intragovernmental organizations.

Additionally, there are accounts of debt that is no longer outstanding.

All amounts are reported in the millions of U.S. dollars.

Reports are published onthe fourth business day of each month, detailing the debt as of the end of the previous month.
datasets.tagLine: High level overview of the Treasuryâ€™s outstanding debts and holdings presented each month in stripped form.

fields.definition: Indicates whether the loan is a guaranteed loan or a direct loan. Guaranteed loan financing is loan financing accompanied by a guarantee, insurance, or other pledge with respect to the payment of all or a part of the principal or interest on any debt obligation of a non-Federal borrower to a non-Federal lender, except for the insurance of deposits, shares, or other withdrawable accounts in financial institutions. Direct loan financing is a disbursement of funds by the Government to a non-Federal borrower under a contract that requires repayment of such funds with or without interest.

datasets.summaryText:
The Monthly Treasury Statement is a multi-table report detailing the financial activities of the U.S. Department of the Treasury for the previous12 months. Money flowing into the Treasury is known as receipts and money flowing out is known as outlays.

A surplus occurs if the total value of receiptsexceeds the value of outlays and a deficit occurs when the value of outlays exceeds the value of receipts.

When a deficit occurs, this report details how the deficit is being funded, such as borrowing from the public or reduction of operating cash.

Further tables categorize spending by department and agency and receipts by specific taxes or other government sources of income.

All values are reported in millions of U.S. dollars.
datasets.tagLine: Summary of the federal governmentâ€™s financial activities, including: receipts and outlays, surpluses/deficits, and means of financing in the case of a deficit.

datasets.name: Status Report of US Government Gold Reserve

apis.tableName: Status Report of US Government Gold Reserve

fields.definition: Type of facility housing gold reserve
fields.tableName: Status Report of US Government Gold Reserve

fields.tableName: Status Report of US Government Gold Reserve

fields.definition: Location of the gold reserve
fields.tableName: Status Report of US Government Gold Reserve

fields.definition: Precious Metals measurement
fields.tableName: Status Report of US Government Gold Reserve

fields.definition: Value assigned to a Fine Troy Ounce by Treasury
fields.tableName: Status Report of US Government Gold Reserve

fields.definition: Reporting date for the data
fields.tableName: Status Report of US Government Gold Reserve

datasets.summaryText:
The U.S. Treasury maintains a large reserve of gold in various locations across the U.S.

The Status Report of US Government Gold Reserve dataset records how much gold is in each location and whether the gold is held in deep storage or if it is gold the mint uses as raw material for the creation of congressional authorized coins. 

The report includes both the weight of the gold in Troy Ounces and the book value in dollars.
datasets.tagLine: The amount of gold the treasury holds in both weight and value.

datasets.name: Gift Contributions to Reduce Debt Held by the Public

apis.tableName: Gift Contributions to Reduce Debt Held by the Public

datasets.summaryText:
This dataset records the monthly total of donations to the Treasury to reduce the public debt. Donations can consist of money, outstanding government obligations, or property that is sold for cash.

Information is available as far back as 1996 on a yearly basis and in Fiscal Year 1998 the report includes monthly values.
datasets.tagLine: Summary of gifts donated to the United States Government to reduce debt held by the public.

datasets.name: Interest Expense on the Debt Outstanding

apis.tableName: Interest Expense on the Debt Outstanding

datasets.summaryText:
The Interest Expense on the Debt Outstanding report is a monthly summary of the cost of interest on U.S. debt, including U.S. Treasury notes and bonds, foreign and domestic series certificates of indebtedness, notes and bonds, savings bonds, Government Account Series (GAS), State and Local Government series (SLGs) and other special purpose securities. 

Beginning in 1988, there is yearly information available and a separate table with monthly totals for the current year.
datasets.tagLine: Monthly summary of the cost of interest on U.S. debt

datasets.name: Schedules of Federal Debt

fields.definition: Reporting date for the data
Tier one of a two-tier hierarchy for categorizing federal debt. Indicates whether the debt is held by the public or part of intragovernmental holdings.
Tier one of a two-tier hierarchy for categorizing the change in federal debt.
The fiscal year to date change in federal debt for the month of the report
The change in federal debt for the month of the report.
Tier two of a two-tier hierarchy for categorizing federal debt.
Tier two of a two-tier hierarchy for categorizing the change in federal debt.

datasets.summaryText:
The Schedules of Federal Debt dataset contains monthly changes and Federal Debt managed by the Bureau of the Fiscal Service, including debt held by the public and intragovernmental debt holdings.

These two categories are further broken down into principal debt, accrued interest payable, and net unamortized premiums/discounts. 

Sub-tables detail the holders of intragovernmental debt, the securities that make up debt held by the public, and interest expense specifics. 

All values are reported in millions of dollars and are available on a monthly basis from the beginning of Fiscal Year 2006 to the present.
datasets.tagLine: Federal debt managed by the Bureau of the Fiscal Service and monthly changes, broken out by principal debt, accrued interest payable, and net unamortized premiums/discounts.

datasets.name: Treasury Reporting Rates of Exchange

fields.definition: Exchange rate at which any foreign currency unit will be valued, and reported at, against the U.S. Dollar.
Country and currency for that exchange rate.
Reporting date for the data

datasets.summaryText:
This report provides authoritative exchange rate information to ensure consistency with respect to foreign currency units and U.S. dollar equivalents across all reporting done by agencies of the government

This report covers any foreign currencies in which the U.S. government has an interest, including: receipts and disbursements, accrued revenues and expenditures, authorizations, obligations, receivables and payables, refunds, and similar reverse transaction items. 

The Secretary of the Treasury has sole authority to establish the exchange rates for all foreign currencies or credits reported by government agencies under Public Law.
datasets.tagLine: Treasury Reporting Rates of Exchange provides exchange rate information for foreign currencies and their U.S. dollar equivalent to ensure consistency across reports.

datasets.name: Historical Debt Outstanding

fields.definition: Reporting date for the data
The Total Debt Outstanding represents the face amount or principal amount of marketable and non-marketable securities currently outstanding. Total debt outstanding is expressed as of fiscal year end.

datasets.summaryText:
Historical Debt Outstanding is a dataset that provides a historical summary of the U.S. governmentâ€™s total outstanding debt at the beginning ofeach fiscal year.

This is a high-level summary of historical debt and does not break down its components.
datasets.tagLine: U.S. debt outstanding at the end of each fiscal year.
